Instrument.name: Doppler Wind Experiment for Galileo Probe
Instrument.description: The Galileo Probe Doppler Wind Experiment (DWE) was designed to extract the zonal (east-west) motion of the Galileo entry probe during its descent into the atmosphere of Jupiter. The orbiter measured the probe radio signal frequency every 2/3 seconds and stored the data in a buffer in the Relay Receiver Hardware (RRH) prior to delivery to the orbiter. The Numerically Controlled Oscillator (NCO) frequency is related to the link frequency according to f_link=57*f_uso + f_nco + 1024 where f_uso is the frequency of the orbiter USO (nominally 24.325553 MHz), and f_nco is the nco control word (frequency), nominally 442455 Hz. Due to the finite word length in the RRH buffer (24 bits), the frequency measurement has an inherent digitization error. A slight timing mismatch between the RRH and orbiter clocks occasionally caused the orbiter to request a frequency from the RRH just prior to a frequency measurement. In these cases the orbiter would measure a frequency of zero and results in a discontinuity in the frequency-time profile of about 7 Hz. To correct this, the frequency measurements were averaged during the discontinuities. In all, out of a total possible of 5173 frequency measurements covering a period of 57 minutes, 28.66 seconds, 5015 frequency measurements were made. None of the missed points were consecutive.
